name: 80 Days
description: 1872, with a steampunk twist. Phileas Fogg has wagered he can circumnavigate the world in just 80 days. Travel by airship, submarine, mechanical camel, steam-train and more. Race other players and a clock that never stops in TIME Magazine's Game of 2014.

recommended_requirements: OS: Windows XP+ Processor: 4 Ghz with SSE2 instruction set support Memory: 4 GB RAM Graphics: Intel Iris 6100 equivalent or better DirectX: Version 9.0c Storage: 2 GB available space Sound Card: Present

reviews.review_text: I recieved a code for this game in order to review it, but I was not paid for my review.  Considering this game takes its inspiration directly from my favorite novel by Jules Verne, whether or not to play this game was a no-brainer for me. This game is a great example of an interactive novel. You are Passepartout, Phileas Fogg's valet, and it your job to plan the route that will take you Around the World in 80 Days ( I couldn't resist). As you plan your route, you have to manage the finances which involves purchasing gear that will help speed up travel or be more comfortable, or purchase artifacts or luxury items to sell in other parts of the world. The routes you can take depend on what maps you have, and who you talk to. There are so many ways to travel around the world, and so many side stories to be discovered. Expect multiple playthroughs to discover them all. The only potential drawback with this game is that you have to read everything. There are nice backgrounds to each place you go but the game relies on the players imagination to visualize a great bulk of the action. Overall, this is a very fun game with loads of replayability.   UPDATE: I just want to say that knowing what I now know about this game, I would have paid full price for this game.  Expect a much more fleshed out review coming soon from The Adventure Lantern!
Not much to say. I'm just a bit disappointed by the fact that this game doesn't offer much more than the mobile version, but it's still a great game even if fairly easy.

Bottom line up front!  Pros:  +Takes less than two hours for a full playthrough. +Tons of replayability +Great visuals; it reminds me very much of a well-designed board game. The conveyances in particular are well rendered, which you may see in the screenshots. The map itself is very nice. +Good ambient sound and music +It's a piece of interactive fiction with a story to tell. There aren't 'wrong' choices, just different ones. +The Phineas Fogg health mechanic is EXCELLENT! Instead of managing your character's health, you are charged as Mr. Fogg's valet. You may abuse him or care for him as your whim dictates. +The system is relatively intuitive and operates very much as though you had a globe and touch-menu available in your room. They ported it from iOS or whatever very well. +The game autosaves often, which offers an easy way to treat this as a casual game. I did not mind that I couldn't manually save given the relatively short amount of time it took to play a journey.  Cons:  -Every journey (so far for me) starts from London to Paris. -Playing through a journey sort of wears out the fun. Each journey builds toward the triumphant return to London (if you make it!), so for me starting a new trip right after completing one felt more like a burden than a truly new adventure -Each city, conveyance, and character has its own art, but really the only striking art was the conveyance. The characters are very much colored cameo/silhouettes, while cities are a bit forgettable. -No tutorial or other instruction is readily apparent. It took me half an hour to figure out that it was easier to use the arrow keys to switch between possible routes and an hour to figure out that my character needed particular equipment in order to negotiate quicker passage with the available conveyances.  In all, if you're even considering getting this game then I recommend it. It's a nice way to while away the time on a lazy afternoon or quiet evening, offering a bit of adventure to contemplate. The script author is an excellent writer, and I very much enjoyed seeing what she came up with. I think it's a good bargain at $10. That's how much I would spend on a two hour movie and I expect to get quite a bit more time out of this game than that.

Fantastic choose-your-own adventure. I just finished my third play-through, seeking new routes around the world.   The writing is strong. The game elements provide a meaningful sense of control via managing possession, money, intelligence gathering, and route planning. Yet the game still surprises.

When I picked this game up in a Humble Bundle, I really didn't expect it to be so addictive! I was anticipating mildly interesting interactive fiction, and what I got was a smart, funny reimagining of Verne's novel, packed with interesting characters and seemingly infinite possibilities. I love the steampunk elements - they feel true to the spirit of the original, if not to the letter of it - and the development of Passepartout as a character is excellent. The writing is very rich, and there are some truly affecting moments.   Thanks to the ever-ticking clock you can't explore everything in one game, but every playthrough offers glimpses of possible adventures that you can seek out next time. Every time I finish a journey I want to start again and see what happens if I do something a bit differently - explore a new route, build different relationships, pursue a new achievement. I've got so involved with this game that I still haven't got round to installing the game I actually bought the Humble Bundle to acquire...

80 Days is a fun little game that takes you on a whirlwind of adventure.  PROS: -Great stories and writing -Good music -Simple gameplay -Fun strategy  CONS: -Can get a bit repetitive after a while -Money can be tight -Could do with a bit more interaction with things (in general)  --------------  The fun part of the game aside from the main adventure is managing the money you have. If times are hard, there are ways to earn cash but of course, that means delays in the trip itself. It's also fun to see where people are in their own journeys and the choice to share your own journey is great.   It's not surprising that the game can eventually become repetitive but there's enough stories to keep it from happening for a while. It would be nice if the development team can update the stories from time to time adding more content but it's already a great game as is.
80 Days offers a vividly-written tour of the world, with plenty of branching paths that likely make a highly-replayable experience.
Just try it, there's so much to discover.

One of the best text based adventure game that I've played. The gameplay is fun, the writing is good but the art style and sounds is what make it really immersive.  I own it on pc & android, and the replayability is amazing.

A truly wonderful game that really pushes the envelope on what an interactive fiction game can be finally arrives in desktop format. I cannot reccomend it enough! Give 80 Days a chance and I doubt you'll be dissappointed. Unless you hate words.  Full of heart-warming, tragic and beautiful storylines and as deep as the Atlantic ocean. I've been playing it for over a year now and I'm still regularly surprised by it.

I bought it on sale along with a bunch of other games, didn't get around to it for a couple of months. I was curious and wanted to try it, but the screenshots made me a little reluctant. Honestly going into it, I thought it was going to be a linear, pre-plotted course. I thought the decisions would be in the dialogue, where occasionally you might give advice regarding the next destination.  I was pleasantly surprised. You get to choose the course entirely, also each time you play (or at least every time I've played) the seed changes. I'm not even sure what all that changes, all I know is I've plotted a different course every time I played and each time offered quite a different journey. This game is a lot of fun and really rich with adventure. I did not expect the replayability to be so high, but it truly is great. I've gone on four runs, so far.  On my first run, I was still familiarizing myself with the game and made some poor decisions. We were late, and made it back to London in 90 days (I got stuck in Africa, my only way out was an airship full of people mad at me for riding in on a slaver ship, I had to spend a week and a half begging for money to afford the venture). I was pleased to discover that even once you pass the 80 day mark, you still plot your way home as normal, there's no instant YOU LOSE screen or anything.  On my second run, armed with my new knowledge of how the game works, I pulled off a round-the-world trip in only 60 days! Huzzah!  On my third run, I believe was my trip north, I made it in 50 days. That was quite adventurous.  My most recent run I did not break my record or anything, it was 60-70 days and I took over a ship, beat a champion boxer, and came home with $10,000, and my peak during our trip was $17,000. No banks.
Very good writing. I found it very engaging.

This game is one of my top recommendations to people. If you want a game that will tell you amazing stories, this is it. It also does a fantastic job of making you feel like you're on a journey as you only see snipets of characters' lives before you are whisked away. The writing is superb and the simple presentation encourages your imagination to run wild.  Gameplay-wise it's very simple. It's most like a visual novel with some very simple time, inventory, and money management to push you along.  Representation-wise this game is also fantastic. The world is a crazy steampunk Victorian era. Half the drivers, captains, and pilots as well as incidental characters are women. The racial diversity is also plentiful, as one would hope of a game about traveling around the world. Additionally, half the romance options are female and half are male. If you're turned off by all this SJW crap, you should play the game anyway. It all works in service of building a unique and varied world that's not just entirely populated by white men with brown hair and giving you a sense of the rich tapestry of people that inhabit the entire world.  Overall, you should absolutely pick this game up. It can get a bit repetitive as you repeat travel routes and stories multiple times, but it's not so much that it's a deal breaker. The game is also available on mobile devices, which perfectly suits the traveling nature of the game. I highly recommend you try it.

A fantastic adventure about managing your resources to make it... around the world in 80 days of course! You create your own story; choose what kind of person you are, where exactly you go, and make decisions about everything. Will you have enough money? Will your master enjoy a sea voyage on a freight liner? Will you make new friends...or enemies? You better hurry and find out!

An amazing game. On my first playthrough, I fell in a certain kind of love with a dime novel authoress crossing from Suez to Bombay and managed to get held hostage in India by a band of cultists and I think we only escaped because my benefactor boned her, but I was never able to get him to own up to it.  I love games like this that give you stories you can really tell, and this is one of the best - think the plot-influencing conversation-'em-up of Telltale with the backstory-generating conversation-'em-up of Kentucky Route Zero, set in a brilliantly well-realized world and with the resource management subgame of Faster Than Light. It's brill-o.
Truly excellent, not many games one can say that about.

Fun, thought provoking, tense at times. Great narrative. The art, stories, setting, concept and game mechanics fit together perfectly. Easy to learn gameplay. Enjoyed it and look forward to replaying it.
Fun little game, though not really suited to PC - more mobile.
10/10   Wonderful story line, very engaging game. Can't wait to play it again!
My master may have died but I found sweet sweet gay love 10/10 will play again
80 Days is the best choose you own adventure game. Captivating story line, Jules Verne would be proud. Pack your gentlemans attire and sally forth.
Crazy trips around a steampunk world in more or less 80 days.
A really well written, multi-walkthrough supporting adventure in spirit of Jules Verne's books. On my third playthrough now, and so far it's a completely different journey each time.  8/10
Very good game, but only in English. For not english language natives it's a little hard to understand at 100% the situations and choices.

Unexpectedly, entertaining and stylish! It has many ways of going through it, with many plot twists, that are directed by YOU. Very nice interpretation of classical novel in a 'pre-steam-punk way'. Highly replayable for several times, but still even more gameplay time coulde be added with patches. In general 9/10, worth buying.

A nice, relaxing game for those who don't mind a little reading. Although it starts to feel a little repetetive after a few playthroughs, I still manage to come across some new events and details every now and then. The visuals are nice, just enough for such a game. A tutorial would be helpful at first, however, I got the grip on the game mechanics during the first fifteen minutes or so, so that should not be a big problem for anybody. Overall, 8/10.
This game is extremely fun, with tons of replayability, and a deep script that keeps things frensh. I could not recommend it more highly.

Strategic, very rewarding replayability factor, great stories, only negative would be the lack of describing certain game mechanics but you can figure those out within minutes. Definitely worth a playthrough for casual gamers and anyone who loves a good story and simple gameplay.

A great game with a compelling story. Reminds me of grade school 'Choose your own Adventure' books. Best text game I've played in recent memory. Do not get if you think Michael Bay is a great director.

Genuinely great storyline that you build in your mind as you go along. Playing this game is almost like reading a good book. The fact that you are not the 'hero' of the story also gives it a unique twist and a new perspective on how the story is told and evolves.

I really enjoyed this game, it is just like an interactive book... I was doing so well until I reached the Pacific ocean and then things started to come apart which made for a really intense run in to London at noon on the 80th day...  I seriously recommend this game, its a real breath of fresh air and is immensely fun....

A hiden gem! One of the greatest suprises i experienced so far. high replay value, because: possibilities!  does a great job of bringing highly immersive, beautyful designed gameplay to your couch  where you can take on this extraordinary wager of your respected master phileas fogg, while making heavy deciscions  to achieve victory against real opponents!  you have to be into text a lot, of course... :)  but worth a try.
Lovely game.
A wonderful, beautifully written exploration into an alternative steampunk 1872 with dozens, if not hundreds of hidden storylines, and an infinite number of possibilities.

The Read-A-Game genre is already too full. This is a fact in evidence. That being said, this game is good enough to push a whole shelf of Hatoful Boyfriends and Cinderses into a circular file for. Subtle to the point of obtuseness, its core purpose hides like a cat, leaping out to swat at you and leaping back in before you can really get a handle on it. To fully understand the setting's meaning and your place within it, or even the full breadth of your own character, you'll be many playthroughs in, but to simply have wonders to gape at a few hours will give plenty to see.  One thing worth noting, though, is that actually winning the wager is meaninglessly easy. The only way to lose is to intentionally wander off; any course that points vaguely eastward will get you there in 70 days or less. There is no challenge to be had whatsoever unless you go for the 50- and 60-day achievements, and those who come in looking for a game about finding a way to get Around the World In, say, 80 Days will find themselves disappointed.

While rather basic in gameplay, I find myself very much wanting to recommend this game for various reasons including its storyline and its immersive steampunk napoleonic setting. If you are in any way a fan of 'around the world in 80 days' or if you are intrigued by the thought of travelling the world in an 1800's steampunk world, then I strongly recommend this game to you as you will find a lot to enjoy.  When it comes to gameplay, there is an aspect of money management which involves buying low and selling high in different places, and then choosing an appropriate mode of travel between each location (fast, comfortable and expensive, or slow, uncomfortable and cheap), You have to keep your master happy but also remain responsible with his/your funds throughout the journey. Despite this, the games primary focus is the text-based character interactions and the thoughts and descriptions of the player character when visiting new cities and travelling in different interesting vehicles. The game also features several dialogue choice segments which can influence what other people think of you and your masters opinion of you.  While I have not yet made it all the way around the world in either of my playthroughs (It takes probably a good 3 hours to do so), I find myself frequently wanting to come back to it but rarely end up gettting around to it, hense my fairly low play time. This game is a delight to play if you are in a lazy mood and want a chilled out but entertaining experience that will last an hour or two until you put it aside for next time. Furthermore, this game has a fair amount of replay value as you are able to choose your own journey (you will not get to visit every city / country in one playthrough due to your 80 day / turn time constraint). All in all, as far as casual games go. i give this an 8/10.

Absolutely loved this. Possible to finish a play-through in 1.5-2 hours, and ideal when you want something light to kill time. If you know the original novel, you'll enjoy the tone and style of this game. Even without, it's a light-hearted, fun and surprising piece of interactive fiction. In 1 playthrough I got abducted by pirates, lost a boxing match, led a mutiny to become captain of a ship, got shipwrecked and enjoyed brief romantic dalliances in Russia and New Orleans.

What an amazing game. A literary classic told through fitting music, charming art that while simple never becomes boring and surprisingly deep and involving game mechanics. I was physically unable to stop my journey once it had first begun, and though much of it was played relatively safe there was still plenty of close shaves and action which made the entire experience one of the best adventures I've had in a game in recent memory. Sadly, I did not make the first trip in 80 days, in part due to poor planning but also from being marooned on a small island in the middle of the pacific ocean where Mr. Fogg almost left his senses. I am already excited to start my next playthrough, with so much of the world left to discover I believe it won't be the last one, either.  If I had to have one complaint, only one, it is that I felt like I experienced an abnormally high amount of female characters compared to male ones. From my start in London, over Paris, Copenhagen, into Russia and across the middle east, East-Asia to New Zealand and into the dark heart of Africa and back into Europe, the amount of male characters I encountered could be counted on one hand (and left me wondering where they all were. Replaced by automatons?). On one hand it was humours, given the game takes places in an (albeit fictional) period of time where women were not often seen in these very male-centric professions, on the other the almost total lack of male characters (and the game at one point describing a grizzled boiler-room engineer as a petite Indian women in a beautiful sari) took a little away from the overall immersion, and I had to wonder if it was intentional or if my route just happened to let me encounter every possible pilot, captain and engineer of the feminine persuasion. Either way, I guess I'll see if this changes on my further adventures.

Surprisingly fun! I'm not normally a fan of text-based 'choose your own adventure' games but this one was really great. It really keeps you on your toes the whole time, you never know what's going to happen next.  There's so many different routes you can take and so many different easter eggs that there's lots of replayability too.

So this game is a narrative/sort of strategy like/choice game where you have to help your master to travel around the world in 80 days. Based on the book by Jules Verne.  This game was pretty fun. Interestingly written and always suprising situations one can end up in. I only played one 'round' but there is defintely replayabilty with the dozens of routes you can take. I don't think I will do one again immediately but possible that i'll pick it up in a bit again. Very enjoyable, very quick to play ' a round'.  I'm always bad at strategy, so I lost my money way to quick and ended up having a debt of 33.000, but fortunately it's not a main component of the game. You can keep lending money without actual problems and just play the game for the story/adventure.  Recommend.

I got this game as part of a Humbe Bundle, though I had it on my wishlist for some time before that. However, I would have gladly paid full price for the game. I've played through two times already and will again soon. There are so many different routes to take in the trip around the world, and so many ways to approach the different situations presented throughout a single playthrough that the replayability of this game is insanely high. If you like games with a lot of decision making and management (and you don't mind a lot of reading) I highly recommend it 80 Days.

Absolutely loved this. Possible to finish a play-through in 1.5-2 hours, and ideal when you want something light to kill time. If you know the original novel, you'll enjoy the tone and style of this game. Even without, it's a light-hearted, fun and surprising piece of interactive fiction. In 1 playthrough I got abducted by pirates, lost a boxing match, led a mutiny to become captain of a ship, got shipwrecked and enjoyed brief romantic dalliances in Russia and New Orleans.

I went into this game knowing very little about it, and I was pleasantly surprised. I've gone around the world a few times now and the adventure has been different every time. I love the visuals and the music (it kept getting stuck in my head the next day). Great game with a lot of replay valuable. The writing is fantastic and the choices you make feel like they matter.
Short game with a lot of replay value, not spectacular but a good game. Worth the $$$.
If only traveling in real life was this much fun.
More choices. And another one. And another one.  And another one.    ... And another one.

I've had little adventure game on my phone for a while, before deciding to get it on Steam, and the variety involved still makes each run-through quite fresh. Easily one of the best pieces of interactive fiction out there today, and a great intro to the world of Jules Verne.

Great idea, but poor execution. Really really wanted to love the game so I played through 2 full trips, but it just confirmed my experience. Feels repetitive and tedious. Choices aren't particularly interesting and consequences don't correlate, so choices/decisions feel even more irrelevant. Buggy, cumbersome user-interface (epecially suitcases and maps). I played through two full trips. First trip took way longer than 80 days. Second trip I barely made it under 80 days, but only by always choosing the most obvious/safe/known decision paths (e.g. avoided talking to strangers as that usually stretched the story/travel time), which was dull and boring. I get that it's meant to be an experience, not about the objective of 80 days, but the experience wasn't particularly rewarding for me personally. The stories that wove together weren't fun or interesting or even necessarily imaginative.
I don't even know what I'm supposed to be doing in this game. Nothing is explained and it's not clear what the goal is or why you should care about any of it.

I enjoyed at first but then stoped playing because I got tired of the looney liberal political views of the writer of the diologue. It got really boring after awhile. I'm a victim all my problems are someone else's falult.zzzzzzzzzzz

Guess I should have watched a gameplay video. Obviously almost everyone who wrote a review likes this game.  I will say that for the type of game this is, it is well designed and implemented. It is basically a choose your own adventure.   I haven't played this type of game before and unfortunately I found it to be incredibly dull. I don't care if my choices matter if the results of my choices are boring, not matter what I choose. Also, to make it through this game you have to record fascinating details such as 'pocket watches sell well in Moscow'. How interesting, can't wait to learn more.
